review_title: product analysts and data scientists roles
pros: Most people joined because it's Google and yes it owns many products that people can't live without today so that means working here makes you proud but that's about it. Culture was much more inclusive, open, and direct when Larry/Sergey still run the company but it has changed my friend...

They bad mouth about people who are NOT in their circle of trust and just want to get rid of them instead of helping them to grow. Horrible.
Advice to Management
Get rid of your arrogant PA/DS ladder executives. They don't know what they are talking about when it comes to building a healthy analyst community. All they want is to show how smart they are without understanding the real needs of the analysts who are below L7. Wake up! Or you will LOSE more people.

review_title: Great perks and overall structure but does not live up to stated ethics and ideals
pros:
Great job security
Clear path to promotion
Smart colleagues
Excellent career development resources
Diverse workplace
Creative freedom and autonomy
Effective feedback processes
cons:
Can be quite political 
Multiple teams working on the same project
Some loud and disrespectful employees
Sexual and racial harassment/discrimination happens more often than it should given their external messaging/image they project
Not true to their stated ethics
Advice to Management
Don’t punish victims of discrimination and harassment for others mistakes by making them switch projects or making them go on mental health leave. 
Be more forthcoming about others working on the same project and facilitate communication instead of pitting people against each other.
Don’t be evil - don’t profit from anti-science misinformation opportunists.

review_title: Still good, but has become a big company.
pros: Hiring & people philosophy. Hire very selectively to get very good people, then pay & treat them well to keep them.
cons:
Difficult to find a good role in the company.
- 75%+ (90%?) of projects are worthless/pointless & destined to go nowhere. On these projects, you can lead a team & the culture is typically good - but your work will never have a real impact.
- At most 25% of projects (probably less) have any chance of having much impact. On those projects, its very difficult to get a role as more than a cog. Also, those teams can afford to (and tend to) have a crappier culture & push people much harder because people want to work on them.
Most people end up working on things they aren't really interested in, or in roles they wouldn't take or stay-in at other companies.
Management quality varies *a lot*. I've seen some managers who were good at their job and also decent human beings. I've seen some that absolutely didn't deserve their roles, and/or that were vey sleazy. Google will basically always consider your manager to be correct in any dispute/disagreement with you, so a bad/sleazy manager can be very bad for your career at G.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Senior management cares only about creating good appearance of a healthy company
pros:
- still lots of great & smart people to work with, but the numbers are dwindling
- *some* tech and dev infra is really cool and ahead of times
- company brand that still means a lot to many
cons:
Lots of great people are leaving and being replaced by people that are very junior, or with senior people with values that didn't use to be common at Google.

Senior management is often more interested in just creating an appearance of a happy and healthy company, rather than actually solving some hard problems.

A lot of technical debt that is increasingly hard to address due to the scale of the company.

In spite of increasingly making more and more money, the management invests less and less back into the company and its employees.
Advice to Management
Add "Don't be evil" back to the corporate code of conduct. Revisit the company values. Invest heavily into the core infra and people that power the company.

review_title: Incredible benefits and compensation, great coworkers, difficult work
pros: If you are looking for a large company to work and grow comfortably in, this is the place to be. The benefits are everything you've heard and more, though work expectations are high. Almost all of my coworkers were high-performing diligent workers and the management was heavily hands-on.
cons:
Performance review cycles and promotion can be cumbersome, and the general size of the company means bureaucracy and communication between departments is difficult. Internal divide between the treatment of contract workers and full-time workers causes friction, and the companies mission and direction are becoming increasingly corporate.
Advice to Management
Less rigorous performance review cycles, more rewards for core role performance vs. extraneous project work

pros:
- compensation
- benefits
- office perks
- products with billions of users
- public commitments to diversity, equity, inclusion, and the environment
cons:
- it's a large company now and has lost it's ability to move fast (product dependent)
- increased bureaucracy: getting anything of consequence implemented requires 10+ types of reviews (code, design, a11y, privacy, sre, logging, legal, QA, support, i18n, capacity, security, leadership), many of which have overburdened and slow reviewers
- senior staff and managers spend ~40% of the year doing performance review tasks in the background (self-assessments, peer feedback, calibration, promo committees)
- mostly use internal proprietary tech which comes with increased maintenance burden through technical mandates and deprecations
Advice to Management
Stop being a tech island

review_title: Good for fresh graduated, bad for senior IC
pros:
- Company generally treat employee well although the trend is down.
- Friendly internal transfer, global mobility
- Engineer productivity and infra are great
- SVP level is great. CEO looks too tired to make good decisions. 
- Bottom level rock-stars are great
cons:
- Slow career growth speed. Not rock-star friendly.
- Many unnecessary hiring and caused many good people leave. It means either its own system can't grow people, or intently replace existing people.
- Perf Review was great but becoming a mess these cycles. Many wrong promotions.
- Don't see any "3 respects". Many managers are very arrogant, even rude. 
- Please don't work in any remote office including NY, SEA. Go to MTV.
- Old groups did many useless projects. 90% KRs are useless. New groups management level is not stable at all.
- Founders are retired in their best age.
Advice to Management
- Hire correct people. Hire necessary.
- Treat rock-star better. Apple did this much better than Google.
- Business oriented, don't let team busy but output rubbish.

review_title: Bad Promo Process and Mediocre Salary
pros: Google has an awesome company culture and perks. Culture: management is accessible, your voice can be heard at team meetings and even all-hands meetings, people respect you, and I always felt cared about as a person. Perks: I thoroughly enjoyed the free breakfast/lunch/dinner, baristas, gym, commuter bus, and subsidized massages.
cons:
Google has to make some serious changes to improve its performance management and promotion processes. Called "Perf", it's a twice a year process that managers and staff alike despise because it takes up enormous amounts of time and results in questionable promotion decisions. 

In Finance, approximately 10% of the team can get promoted in any given Perf cycle and there are only two per year. I recommend learning about Google's internal level system during the hiring process and asking what level your role is before you accept the job offer. Talk to a friend or contact and see if the leveling of your role is reasonable to start with. I was hired at too low of a level and then slow (3 years) to reach my first promotion. 

Finance Levels at Google (rough work experience required):

L3 Financial Analyst (1-2 years)
L4 Financial Analyst (2-4 years)
L5 Senior Financial Analyst (4-6 years)
L6 Finance Manager (6-8 years)
L7 & L7.5 Senior Finance Manager (8+)
L8 Finance Director (12+)

L5 is the terminal level for many Finance employees. It's extremely difficult to get into management. L6 and above are very political promotions. For promotions at levels 3-5, they are largely time-based (2 years on average for L3/L4, 3 years for L5). Super strong performers do not get promoted more quickly, contrary to what Google claims. 

While total compensation (salary + 15% bonus + equity) is often competitive, the salary component is quite low and makes it hard to afford the SF Bay Area cost of living, especially in your first year before you get a bonus and before any of your equity vests.
Advice to Management
Higher base salaries, more roles outside of the SF Bay Area, and a more equitable/lightweight perf/promo process. Don't hire people at unfairly low levels. Example: Ivy League MBA graduate with 8 years of banking experience hired as an L4 Financial Analyst. Promote high performers at a pace much quicker than average. I've seen many good people leave because they were passed up for promotion too many times while working hard.

pros: Surely one of the best companies to work for, I consider myself as extremely lucky to have spent several years at Google.
cons:
Google's middle management has become extremely complacent, and there is limited room for growth as those middle managers are neither leaving their jobs or nor very interested in promoting their teams. It is literally impossible to grow from say mid level to Sr Leadership. Eventually people give up and leave. Also - their performance review system is broken. People have been in tears for not getting an "exceeds" rating.
Advice to Management
Kick/manage those white elephants out.

review_title: Great place to work. Cloud is becoming a different company.
pros:
Benefits
Collaborative atmosphere
Smart and driven colleges
Massive growth in Cloud and potential to shape.
cons:
The Google Cloud part of the company is turning more and more into a very traditional B2B Enterprise company as the workforce has been grown aggressively through external hires from Oracle, SAP and Microsoft. Google's culture is much less present there, with more emphasis on hirarchy, 'sales culture' and politics compared to Google's traditional very entrepreneurial, hands-on and 'engineering culture'.

Still a good place to work with collaborative, smart and friendly coworkers. Just not necessarily how you would expect Google to be.

review_title: Amazing if not for a fatal flaw.
pros:
+) Extremely high compensation. When I switched to another big tech company, I actually ended up taking a small paycut despite getting a promotion.
+) Very flexible working hours (I had a coworker who worked four ten hour days and took Fridays off)
+) Excellent perks. Free food for three meals a day (of very good quality) plus snacks, and plenty of "teambuilding" events that are basically excuses to enjoy an afternoon off with coworkers.
+) A few years working at Google will make your resume and let you join pretty much any company you choose.
cons:
-) Extremely political. Google is all about bringing your whole self to work, so long as your whole self is progressive. There are a number of activists within the company who will protest at the drop of a hat. This may be a positive for some people, but anyone on the right, or even in the center of the political spectrum will have to bite their tongue to remain employed. 
-) Getting promoted within the company is a difficult ordeal, and the effort may not match the results.
Advice to Management
I'd say to focus on work, not activism, but it's probably too late. I fully expect activists to claim more and more control within the company, and for Google's mission to fully slide into social justice, as opposed to making good products for customers.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: A Big Company that pretends it's a Startup
pros: Amazing tech, excellent benefits, a very generous employer. Salaries are not top of the line, but certainly high; office amenities are well documented; there are various budgets and stipends for training and learning; out of hours on-call times get (some) time off in lieu.
cons:
Many policies are enforced unevenly, the dismissal of various "troublemakers" have made the news and should be reviewed carefully. There is a significant amount of gaslighting and straight up dishonesty about policies, especially around topics where it is easy to be vague such as communications and confidentiality.

The positives above only apply to Engineering teams. Life is very different in Sales, I am told. 

While there are many claims about "we're a family" and "community" and so on, there is the usual strong disconnect between senior and exec management and the individual contributors at the coalface. This is expected in a huge company, but as it fails to admit that it is a huge company, it takes no steps to correct this.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Interesting experience, but not what I expected or hoped for.
pros:
People.
General culture.

Couldn't tell you about the perks, because I joined during the pandemic, so there are no perks.
cons:
Pay isn't quite what it should be, though they claim it's "market rate". It's not.. Well below, but they figure they'll get someone since the app rate is so high.

If you join them, make sure you join actual Google, not wind up in some company they acquired that is going to take years to acclimate. You'll never get to experience actual Google life. I joined Google for the Google experience, and instead got the GoogleNotGoogle experience.
Advice to Management
Be more competitive on pay and work on proper leveling. Also, when you acquire a company. Don't take so long to work on properly integrating the company. It especially makes it hard to transition to any other team in Google when you've never touched any of the tools.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Really cool place to work, they've taken the time to make the office feel like a relaxed place to be in. Also, having Google on my CV has been invaluable - recruiters will always ask about it and so I feel it gives me a bit of an edge. I was always working on some really exciting, cutting edge projects and each day was varied with what I was working on. It's hard to get bored here.
cons:
The work/life balance wasn't so good; it was very easy to find yourself working late 3-4 times a week. Most of my projects were lone-working so I didn't have much opportunity to make friends or learn from peers/management. There also wasn't much space for internal progression.
Advice to Management
None.

pros: Google's culture is very open and encourages employees to work together. Company executives publish all information to all employees every week. Employees' contributions to others are highly valued.
cons:
New employees are always joining the company. The good side is that they bring in different perspectives, but the down side is that the culture is gradually changing. For example, in recent years Google has a culture that does not prioritize customers.
Advice to Management
It's hard to maintain the great culture that Google had when it was founded, but management must strive to provide the best possible workplace.

pros: Human resource is known as “People Operations” at Google to make it sound more friendly. This department uses data to take a proactive approach to ensure the happiness of employees. For instance, when Google noticed a higher turnaround rate for women, they looked at data and noticed most were new mothers, which led to the implenetation of a generous maternity leave policy.
cons:
Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!
Advice to Management
Employees need and appreciate a manager who takes time to coach and challenge them, and not just when they’re behind.

review_title: Very high job security but low career growth
pros:
- Very high job security 
- Great perks (obv)
- Co workers are great at coding and algorithms. Very nice, Mostly the type just looking for a comfy job that pays a lot so they could buy a house and hang with their SO and kids.
cons:
- Slow career growth (manager told me I was 6mo away from a promo for years).
- Employees have 0 business sense (Why do we need to make money with this new product when Ads prints so much money?). This applies to GoogleX too. 
- Low abitions. Both with company goals and personal goals.
Advice to Management
- More ambitious goals. 
- Lower the red tape.

review_title: Amazing brand name but Recruiters are ALL facing burnout
pros:
Amazing Brand
Great benefits and perks
Competitive Salary for Recruiters
Great offices and amenities (when they're open)
cons:
Work from Home decisions have been very fickle
Microcosm of culture depending on what Product Area you're in
Recruiters are all burned out - so many requisitions - so little support from leaders
Not a representative workforce and especially not in Staffing/Recruiting - very few black and latinx recruiters - and almost no leaders from these backgrounds which is puzzling given our commitments to DEI
Psychologically Safety really varies by team - it's hard to be vocal bc you're always nervous of consequences and don't want to rock the boat
Advice to Management
work on culture 
be more aggressive about holding leaders accountable to DEI commitments
bring back the magic of Google - there are so many amazing companies now - we cannot rest on our laurels

review_title: Best perks / tech of any company I've worked for, but decisions are now slow
pros: Can't beat the perks (international travel opportunities, education stipend, etc.) and the technical innovation you are surrounded by pretty much anywhere else; total comp pay is high but not as high as that of Facebook (still very solid though) and the things you can work on are more varied (Google is in so many industries).
cons:
It can take a really long time for senior leaders to make a decision because it's such a big company and you are rewarded for steering the ship slowly and safely, not for risk-taking. Like any big company, it also has its own team and internal politics that result in building what someone wants (maybe for their own personal passion or career advancement) and not for what the customer might want or what's best for Google.

pros:
We're Social Beings. People need people. ...
We Need to Have Purpose. I think work provides an avenue to fulfill a purpose – or at least the feeling of it. ...
Feeling Productive is Good for the Soul. ...
To Maintain a Standard of Living. ...
We're Creative Beings.
cons:
Willpower. Gotta get jamming on this new project, but Netflix says you still have 4 episodes of Tiger King to watch...
Difficulty sticking to a routine. The order you do things at work is almost never the order you do things at home. It can be tough to mirror your schedule and processes once outside the office.
Missing important calls or pings. Oops, my phone was on do not disturb and I missed a meeting! Or my boss slacked me and asked to prioritize something else and now it’s 4:45pm ...
Calling UberEats anyways. You thought you were saving money, didn’t you? Blam-o! $20 minimum and a $5 fee for the higher rated Thai place. Should’ve remembered to buy bread …
Power naps. This could arguably could be in advantages … unless it accidentally lasts 45 minutes after your delivered double entree Thai lunch.
Boredom. Those office convos? Kinda missing Susan’s cat stories, eh? How long can you go without seeing another living human being?
Working slowly. Sometimes the office has an energy. Sometimes your home does not.
No second monitor. How did I ever work without two giant screens looming above me??? All 74 of my tabs are essential!
Iffy WiFi. At home or in a cafe, when the wifi start to spaz and you switch locations a couple of times but honestly spend more time parking and ordering a 6-shot mint mojito coffee with coconut milk and 16 grains of sugar than doing work.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Great company if you fit the culture
pros:
Fantastic facilities
Abundant resources
Very smart coworkers who are team players
High morals
Complete independence and trust for employees
Lots of opportunities
cons:
Focus on documentation over accomplishment
Waterfall development
Everything is overly planned with a lot of energy spent on getting consensus
Everything is bottom up with little direction from management
Questions are answered by pointing you in the right direction instead of giving you the answer.
Incredibly long ramp up times
Everything is done differently with unique tools
Advice to Management
Introduce more top down coordination, planning and standardization
Adopt agile methodology and focus on what is done, not the documentation around what was done

pros: There's a reason why the company is known as being the best of the best. Genuine interest in work/life balance; takes feedback from employees; no micro management; perks are the best of any employer. Free breakfast, lunch and dinner if you want it. Multiple professional baristas on site for expertly brewed coffee; snack and drinks cupboards on every floor in the office; gym and swimming pool and classes on site. Massages, even a hairdresser and post office and bank in the office! At the end of every year you get a salary review/increase and a stock refresh. Management and fellow employees are all unbelievably talented and wonderful colleagues who are keen to lift and support each other.
cons:
Can be slow to get promoted and progress up the company. Upward mobility is hard.
Advice to Management
Continue promoting from within; focus on your current existing employees rather than driving a huge focus on external recruitment. You have an unbelievably talented workforce - focus on them!

review_title: Prestigious, fascinating, great benefits but EXHAUSTING and poor work/life balance
pros: It's GOOGLE. Great benefits, probably the most stable OTE pay for a sales role EVER, perks galore, and the chance to develop yourself and shape your career path with the world's greatest resources.
cons:
Despite the perks and the prestigious logo, work/life balance is poor. Google is filled to the brim with over-achievers always intent on promo or their next role. This, along with an INSATIABLE demand for growth, leads to unhealthy work/life balance. My teammates and I regularly burnout and get sick from exhaustion. Management knows about this and still lacks compassion. Instead of truly "seeing you," they say something like "working hard doesn't mean you are working smart." This sentiment hurts, especially when mgmt is constantly throwing you last-minute AIs and adding new OKRs/KPIs.
Advice to Management
Your employees give their lives to Google: respect that more and meet employees where they are at. LISTEN/be curious about work/life balance struggles, understand that burnout is becoming more acute as the pandemic keeps going. Please revisit your "Return to Office" policy and comms, which created a tsunami of fear and anxiety across the company. You've got plenty of money and resources to up morale. Even a little something would mean a lot.
5 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Plenty of perks like food, health insurance, etc.
cons:
It almost feels like a cult full of toxic positivity. The work culture is quite unhealthy - some people are in the office as early as 6 am and leave as late as 10 pm to hit their targets. Targets are often set at unattainable levels that require this kind of time commitment. They also emphasize “culture fit” in the hiring process, but if you start in sales and would like to move to something more gratifying that you would experience more success in, it’s nearly impossible. All that matters is how much money you make them.

pros: Google will throw perks at you as a way to make you stay; the food is great (outside of MTV), the offices are beautiful and there's a lot of smart people to work with.
cons:
I don't even know where to start.

Internal mobility sucks: the ladder transfer process is extremely bureaucratic; depending on your current role, hiring managers won't even reply to your email; you need to know the right people to get the job, otherwise you'll keep hitting the wall. 
That said, if you ever hear "gTech", run like the devil runs from the cross. One of the luring tactics they'll use to get you to enter gTech is to say moving internally is a real possibility -- except that gTech hires engineers to sales support roles, and other orgs at Google don't give a gTech engineer any credit (because we have nothing to show for our work, which is not technical, not interesting, not relevant). I was naive enough to believe the job description, which sounded actually interesting, just to start in a role that led me to depression and undermined my coding skills, because my main task (when I wasn't in useless meetings) was archiving emails.
Don't do that to yourself. If you want to be a Software Engineer at Google, postpone your application and study for an actual SWE role. Don't join gTech thinking it opens doors, because it actually closed them.

Now, for those who care about Diversity, Equity and Inclusion: Google doesn't. Of course, the image we get is that everything is a shining rainbow of happiness, inclusivity and cooperation, but if you speak up about things that actually matter, they will make you shut up. The louder you are, the bigger the consequences. Google is mostly made of privileged demographics that couldn't care less about any event or initiative about DEI internally. What ends up happening is that the underrepresented people end up getting yet another expectation of DEI champion, and that will only slow down their progress, productivity and, ultimately, compensation and career progression.

Overall: the food is great, but it's not worth the trouble 👍
Advice to Management
Stop and rethink this role

review_title: Great people and benefits, too much bureaucracy
pros:
- Colleagues are as a rule friendly, helpful, intelligent.
- Easy transfers between projects and orgs, many different and interesting problems to work on.
- Great office benefits, global presence makes travel + work easy. Good pay.
- Great work-life balance if you want it, little danger in getting managed out. Good (but slow) advancement opportunities as IC or EM if you want to work hard.
cons:
- So much process and bureaucracy. Most of it is well-intentioned but project planning and launch is very CYA
- Slow-moving by default. Everyone is capable of being very productive, but moving fast doesn't seem rewarded much more than moving slow.
- Giant company, no individual project gets much exec attention or moves the needle much on P&L
Advice to Management
Admit to yourselves and employees that Google is not the fun-loving, fast-moving startup it used to be.

pros:
Please note that I am working for Google Cloud which is a pretty independent unit within the greater Google.

- Very smart and creative but humble people, you won't find the brashness and blabla that are seen in corporate environmnets too often
- High level of trust, no micro-management, managers are subject matter experts and not just "managers
- Employees are entrusted with big responsibilities from an early point on and encouraged to take on projects that go beyond the usual scope of the core job 
- Possibility of taking on a 20% project which does not even need to be connected to core job
- Techy, data driven, nerdy, quirky culture
- Great technology + GCP is getting more and more successful particularly among startups/ tech companies
- Intriguing environment, just check things like "Talks at Google" on YouTube
- Great benefits, salary, stock options
cons:
- Google Cloud, particularly in the startup/ SMB segment feels a bit like startup itself which also means chaotic at times - Many processes aren't well defined
- Too many complex, self built tools 
- Google is quite insistent on hiring in Dublin, particularly in Cloud SMB. This will need to change since Dublin is an objectively less attractive city than say Amsterdam or Berlin
Advice to Management
Abandon the concept of Dublin as a hub.
Especially since Covid it is perceived even less favourably by people and people are even less willing to relocate there for a job.
If you keep hiring in Dublin instead of offering more remote, in-country positions or positions at local offices such as Amsterdam, the pool of talent to pick from will be small and the quality of our poeple will go down
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Google's custom stack is both its greatest asset and its greatest liability
pros:
- Fantastic benefits
- It's Google
- Lots of opportunities to learn new skills
cons:
Keep in mind that my experience is limited to a single group within Google.
- Work happens in isolation
- No team culture
- Work is 45% research, 45% documentation, 10% coding (being generous)
- I had 4 bosses in less than 2 years
- Diversity and inclusion is cool and necessary but takes too much room
- Move up or move out culture
Advice to Management
Team cohesiveness needs to be improved.

pros:
1. Work with some of the very smartest people in the industry.
2. Perks on perks, endless perks, you won't even be able to find them all on the public internet, prepare to be pampered daily.
3. Some of the coolest tech offices in the world. And you can visit any of them at any time if you happen to be stopping by! (Not right now because of COVID, obviously)
4. Quite possibly the best internal tools in FAANG.
5. Stock is a rocketship right now.
6. Get first-hand insight on some really cool and cutting-edge projects. Although unfortunately, you won't always be allowed to talk about them externally.
7. On average, great WLB (30-40 hrs/wk). But as with any company, it's entirely team-dependent, so do your research before joining a team!
cons:
1. Pay is not as crazy as it was, say in 2010. (But still among the top in the industry)
2. Still some uncertainty around WFH policy.
3. Some of the projects are really cool but might never see the light of day. Just how big tech is though, sometimes.
Advice to Management
Take a clearer stance on WFH policy, one way or the other.

review_title: If the guy who threatened my job could get promoted, this is not the place where I want to work.
pros:

Got to travel
Occasional perks made some things nicer, but they were often ephemeral. 
FTE status for extra perks sometimes.
cons:
Too much to complain about. I deleted a lot that would have probably identified me. 

My first manager threatened my job in a private meeting. Told me other managers were gossiping about me. He told me my job was in danger if I kept submitting negative feedback about his (eventually proven to be bad) idea. I communicated that the expectations set when I started were being abandoned. I told him how my last job they hired me away from stuck to their expectations at least, and he told me to go back to my old job. 

Another manager, in a small meeting of himself and some ITRs did it to a group of people once too. "Remember, we're the ones who sign your conversion papers". I didn't feel secure and was often anxious around management, because I never knew who was gossiping about me and who wasn't. 

How would you react to this kind of hostility? I was too afraid to report him, so I watched him get promoted away from his mistakes and failed responsibilities. I was mentorless, directionless, and the guy who I thought was looking out for me was just looking out for himself. 

This kind of trash happened more than once, and the managers should be ashamed of themselves for starting cliques and discouraging honest, candid feedback. 

This program was not googly, and this is not the only reason.
Advice to Management
It feels like upper management advocated for managers' interests more than ITRs, and didn't chime-in enough to help us when other departments demanded more from us. We got steamrolled and it was almost always one-sided.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Salary, Customer Interactions, Designing cutting edge solutions for customers
cons:
Bureaucracy, endless reporting, endless perf cycles (multi-month twice per year), needy leadership; demands for status updates, docs, process-related artifacts even if the doc does not serve a customer-facing purpose ... For every external facing task I do there seems to be a required internal task.
Advice to Management
Ease up on the sales process stuff and let the sales teams do their work. Bonuses are paid based on quota attainment, but for some reason, perf is all about people and process. If a seller hits their quota, why does it matter what specific documents they created or if they did a POC? Ease up on the sales process stuff!

the company is absolute chaos, everything overlaps, no one is sure who does what, everyone competes hard to be seen as the winner
it’s very siloed, all the different bits of google run as pretty separate companies so for anyone or team in roles that have to deal with more than one of the engineering groups, it is very hard to get them to work together.

review_title: Great culture, benefits, and most importantly, people
pros:
- inclusive culture & hiring practices
- great colleagues / partners
- perks are top notch from health benefits to food, gyms and speaker series
- support of growth / development
- collaborative
- great office environment and support while working remotely
- a techstop, thank you!
cons:
- never seemingly properly staffed 
- always a focus on ruthless prioritization due to having too much being asked of you, leaves you feeling stretched constantly (so this could be a positive if you like breadth over depth)
Advice to Management
- while it's said that leadership can 'say no', it doesn't happen frequent enough
- focus on creating some redundancies across teams so key man risks don't happen so frequently, causing huge holes when teammates depart or projects grow in scope but not in headcount.
2 people found this review helpful

review_title: Huge potential for impact but too much bureaucracy
pros: The individuals are wonderful - you'll meet the smartest and kindest people you've ever known. Even if leadership is questionable, the people on the ground are wonderful. Also, the scope for impact is phenomenal.
cons:
So much redtape -- 7 years ago, Google still had that scrappy and entrepreneurial culture even as a big organization. But now, it's nearly impossible to get things done because 100s of people need to approve of any small decision
Advice to Management
Stop hiring senior management externally - promote more from within!

ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Overall, Google is a nice place to work. There's a high concentration of smart people and loads of interesting things going on.
Cons
Avoid 'gTech' at all costs, especially as an engineer.. It's a highly political and dysfunctional org where everything is about "helping" customers or sales (never with anything interesting though) and making up bs metrics about what you've done. 

They'll lure you in with all the benefits of working at Google and the promise to work on exciting things. Don't let them fool you, the actual work is mind numbing and the culture is terrible. gTech is easily the worst place to be in Google and you'll regret joining within a year. Attrition is very high and internal transfers to a decent org are hard, so most people leave pretty soon.
Advice to Management
Consider how the gTech org is bringing your brand down.

review_title: Office politics and hierarchy hurt Google’s potential
pros: Perks, potential to be great
cons:
Office politics are horrendous; hierarchical set up where Directors are over-empowered; boys club culture persists in many divisions.
Advice to Management
Fix the perf system so that it rewards collaboration and doesn’t foster individualism and “ownership” that can translate into idea stealing. Take a good look at orgs that are male dominated and survey women about their experiences. Give staff opportunity to confidentially review Directors and report abuse of power.

review_title: Great pay, nice people, a little boring
pros: Management is nice. There are very few bad apples and most people who work there are pretty smart. The engineering culture is solid. You can move around fairly easily. Promotion (at least at the basic levels) is fair.
cons:
The job is a little boring. A lot of what made it famous early on -- 20% time, for instance, and real transparency from leadership, to name two such things -- have withered away as the company has grown to its current global status. It's a big company with a lot of bureaucracy. There's a lot of red tape and approvals to go through nowadays. No one at Google today is creating the next Gmail in their free time.

pros: Free food, nice offices, resources for mental health that you'll probably need after working there for a while.
cons:
In my experience the focus has been on rushing something out the door. Not necessarily something good, or something completely functional (even for the minimal features in the MVP), just something. Frequently software is rushed, testing is skimped on, and higher up engineers are unwilling to learn modern software development practices to improve software performance, reliability, developer experience, and user experience.

If you do not like to cut corners, do not work at Google. After spending 4 years here, being told by 3 managers that I care too much about my work and spend too much time making it right (while simultaneously being dinged on perf for it being 'not right enough'), and witnessing Google's willingness to protect sexual abusers and the bottom line over its purported values, the veneer of friendliness seems very disingenuous.

review_title: Google Shopping/Express - Difficult experience at best
pros: Lots of perks, such as food, shuttle, personal and professional development classes. Good, smart, hard-working peers.
cons:
Google Shopping (formerly Express) was quite the hot mess, essentially an immature, messy start-up despite being a part of the larger Alphabet family. No clear vision or direction, more like 'let's throw stuff on the wall and see what sticks.'

Very frustrating experience to be a part of -- unrealistic work loads on the shoulders of a few, constant clashing between different groups that were supposed to be collaborative and working towards the same goal (i.e. the customer). Very hard to make data-driven decisions for the customer with constant bullying and micro-aggressions from the Category Management team to push their specific agenda (i.e. revenue goals and merchant favoritism).

A constant revolving door of contractors who did the majority of the work, who were under constant pressure, overworked, and under-appreciated and under-valued. Direct management of such contractors couldn't even be bothered to manage, engage, or acknowledge these extended workforce folks.
Advice to Management
Doesn't really matter anymore since almost all of Shopping was cut/let go, redistributed, or left...because it was a FAILURE. 

But essentially it's pretty clear that when you stray from your core mission and values, you all but guarantee failure. Also not hiring people who actually had eCommerce/retail experience didn't help either. Another prime example of mediocre people milking the company and never really get evaluated or held accountable for results. Instead they just get shuffled around, delegating busy work to others, all while cashing in their checks. Alphabet may be huge and making huge profits, but you still gotta trim the fat and cut out dead weight.

review_title: Good gig, tough advancement for women
pros: The benefits are excellent and colleagues are smart and kind. Competitive pay. Good parental leave. Access to a lot of training resources.
cons:
It is hard to advance as a woman, especially if you are not an engineer or a product manager. HR does not deal with investigations in a transparent way. It’s a boy’s club and can be emotionally exhausting. It’s very hard to get promoted, but it’s not a bad place to spend a few years. Unfair things happen all the time. If you can emotionally disengage, you can have a good personal life.
Advice to Management
It’s unacceptable to have meetings with 10 men and no women where things are decided that affect dozens of if not hundreds of people.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Great place to grow and learn steadily in your middle to late career
pros: Benefits and perks are industry-leading, and work culture is very conducive to separating work and life. I feel supported by the policies and management expectations that are put in place to encourage wellness, honest feedback, and time off when necessary. The average tenure of a Googler seems longer than the average big-tech (ex-FB), and I think that's due to the long-term mobility you can find here - whether it's across business units, movement to XFN teams, and even to new markets/offices.
cons:
Very large and ever-growing company creates a lot of product and workstream silos, potential for overlap, and definitely an incredibly heavy consensus-driven culture. Working here teaches you to collaborate and manage internal stakeholders, but this comes at the expense (sometimes) of moving quickly and feeling autonomous.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
- Great colleagues (for the most part) - interesting people who genuinely want to help and support one another.
- Great learning opportunities as you can virtually sign up to learn anything internally as Google has many different teams/orgs/functions.
cons:
Given the size of the company, it might be tough to tie your work to the impact you are making. If "what" you do matters and if you are not passionate about advertising, it can be tough to grow further. Additionally, each team/org has their drawback, whether it is an excessive focus on metrics/target, or how you need to manage upward to get further in the corporate ladder (but one can argue that you need that skill anywhere in life).

review_title: You are a sales person, not an engineer.
pros:
You will get access to the roadmap, and other future looking insights.
If you've never heard of cloud before because you've been building toasters, then it's a good place to start. 
The salary is typically way over market value for your skills.
cons:
You're not technical, and you'll only learn the platform at a surface level. 
Sub-regions (like Canada) are terrible to sales engineers.
The cultural values advertised are not respected in field sales engineering.
Advice to Management
My manager had my job 3 years ago and now manages a team over 10+ people most of whom have more experience. Wake up and smell the googlegiest.

pros: Excellent meals. Generally a great work environment. Superb internal tools. Folks are nice. Very low pressure environment.
cons:
Lots of talent there, but not always clear what to work on. Warehouses full of shelf-ware. Many half baked projects start and are vaporized when they lead nowhere. This is a good strategy for Google - as a monopoly they the can start a 1000 projects - if a couple turn out well they write the others off - as their giant cash machine covers all costs.

One beef; it's harder being older there. Explicit age-ism was very rare, but there was a strong strain of "let's celebrate youth" - the famous "take your parents to work day". Once in a while I was on the receiving side of some condescending nonsense as an "unwoke" ancient. It's precious snowflake central - nice kids - but they've no clue on how the rest of the working world works.
Be the first to find this review helpful

ltant in Boulder, CO
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
My favorite thing about working at Google is the people you work alongside. Everyone I have ever worked with at Google is an intelligent, hard working, and overall kind person. The work environment is also fast paced, ambiguous, innovative and rewarding. The company has a great culture overall and a lot of opportunity for learning and growth.
Cons
It can be difficult to land a role in your location of preference due to high competition and focus on specific hub offices. In addition, job mobility can be harder when you are in business and non-Eng roles. Most positions are also located in expensive cities which may not work as well for people further in their career with greater preference and limitation on where they are willing to live.

review_title: Loads of Commitment for Slightly Above-Average Pay
pros:
Above-Average Pay
Good People for the most part
High-quality Ad Products to sell (relative to competitors)
Solid 401k match and benefits
Global work community
Indirectly supports Alphabet's attempts to solve existential human challenges
cons:
Below average vacation days (inconsistent depending on country)
Wolf-in-sheep's clothing managerial styles / psychological tactics
Undeniable workaholic-culture, despite internal rhetoric to the contrary
"if it ain't completely broke, don't fix it" mentality with internal/external products
Under-staffed (at least in sales), resulting in excessively high client ratios
Under-resourced, creating productivity and scoping dilemmas
Advancement can be impossible if you are on the wrong team, at the wrong level, with the wrong manager
Advice to Management
Re-evaluate your workloads against the average rate of burnout.
Re-evaluate how much revenue or how many clients managed per person is "necessary", and then lower this target.
Don't perpetuate work cultures where workaholism is implicitly or explicitly championed as the 'normal' worker state.
Even the workaholics are showing signs of burnout!
Encourage your product & policy leadership teams to proactively anticipate, respond to and solve for problems, before they snowball into much larger problems that create massive side-effects and productivity drains for other teams (especially client-facing teams).
Be more proactively transparent internally about ethical challenges facing Google, so we hear about them from leadership before we read about them in the media.
Continue taking employee feedback to heart and making significant changes based on that feedback -- don't stop at reminding employees that you are listening -- show demonstrable improvements & beneficial actions, AFTER they have been achieved.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Awesome benefits, very entitled colleagues, not always the greatest culture
pros: Google treats it's people well. While you're working at google, you can trust that your benefits are nearly as good as they get, and your salary is probably about 80% as good as it gets.
cons:
People who are fresh out of college, or maybe have been at Google too long, forget what other jobs in the field are like. The reference for comparison can be very skewed. At the same time, management can talk a big game about the culture that google has, but rarely lives up to the promises of transparency, and innovative thinking, etc. But it's such a big company, I'm sure this is all department by department, team by team.

review_title: Get in, boost your CV, get out. Treat it as 6th year of studies.
pros: You get 3x more attention from recruiters. Salary in top 10% of employers. Free food.
cons:
Extreme competition among engineers (expect being compared with people doing overtime to get promoted). Substandard designers, managers are just promoted engineers (so "manage yourself, I want to code"), custom tech for everything (so most of stuff you learn there you will never use again). Also you feel like playing a game: rules are highly artificial, people are "mastering strategies" to get ahead, nobody really cares about product. When you get in, learn the rules from someone who works there for 4+ years, and don't trust common sense.
Advice to Management
You recruit excellent engineers. Now learn to recruit everything else.

review_title: Do not join Google in this role
pros: -everything related to Google and not related to this role or the GCS org
cons:
Summary: it's not what it used to be anymore

-calling client's that don't want to talk to you and convincing them to do things that are often not needed for them but for Google to generate more money
-learning curve flattens extremley after 3-6 months. After that, just a very well paid call-center job
-no clear career/growth path. Google keeps enforcing level (promo) requirements that force you to do a job that could be done by a computer for 2 years. 2 years ago, you would only have to do that for one quarter. Back in the old days, you would do 20% projects with other teams to get out of GCS. But this becomes harder and harder as most people know how terrible the GCS Org/Job is and simply leave after a short time. It's also very hard to learn any transferable skills as all you do is call people and convince them to stuff (no brain power needed) 
-higher management in central Europe does not have a clear strategy. Feels more like they try to push their own promo as hard as possible. Also, they block any rotation that would help you to get out of GCS to more interesting roles
-Higher management in central Europe always says stuff like "we put you and your career first" - which only applies to the sales roles that almost no one wants to do for a long period of time 
-The level you will be joining on (l2) in GCS is so low that you can't even change to (almost) any other department before a promotion. Even after a promotion, your level is often too low. You are stuck in this role for 2 years + 1-2 years on the next level before you can do anything interesting 
-A location that almost no one likes. That's why they hire local irish people for higher management to enforce the location
Advice to Management
-Vendorize Scaled & Engage, only focus on MMS
-Do not treat Bachelor and Master students the same way. Hire Bachelor on L2 and Master on L3. 
-See GCS as what it is: an entry to Google of high skilled people. Do not force people to stay in this org 
-Realize that Google is no longer the best employer in the market. Treat employees fairly, tell them what the job is like during the interviews
6 people found this review helpful

* Job roles not clearly defined.
* Some exposure to office politics.

review_title: If you're going to work for a giant corporation, it should probably be Google.
pros: Pay/benefits are amazing. Colleagues are intelligent and ambitious. Flexibility to change role if you perform well.
cons:
Chaotic, feels like strategy changes every quarter. If you're on a team, you are likely working in a silo with contractors and agencies. If you lead a team, you will be heavily constrained to build out full time resource. It's a huge multinational without the structure of traditional enterprises.
Advice to Management
Hire more junior, high potential marketers instead of relying on contractors.

review_title: Strong foundational skills to learn while benefitting from the Google ecosystem
pros: So many awesome benefits and perks, and I'm not talking about baristas. Google provides incredible benefits and free resources for employees to learn relevant skills and subject areas that you can use to develop your current role or lead to a new one. I never feel like I run out of things to learn and explore within Google.
cons:
Like all large corporations, it can feel quite bureaucratic and opaque when it comes to certain things, namely HR-related. That said, there are always ways to find answers to your questions in help center pages or a person at Google who can help.
Advice to Management
Let more people work remotely in the coming years to increase the breadth of talent we can bring in.

pros:
* Great salary and bonuses
* Smart colleagues
* Good perks in the office (free food, gym, ...)
* Relative independence towards the hours of work, no micro-management
cons:
* Career progression is slow and gets slower as the number of employees gets higher (e.g. a few years ago, a SWE was expected to ramp-up to L5, while it would be L4 now); also, it could me smarter to move to Facebook/Amazon/... and come back to get a higher level
* Bureaucracy
* Poor independence regarding the projects (ton of reviews, etc.)
* Too much focus on inclusion / following the trends (e.g. Black Live Matters, etc.) rather than on the products (i.e. it became a highly political organisation)
Advice to Management
Less sweets, more meat

review_title: Great place to be an admin!
pros:
- Lots of opportunities for projects beyond traditional assistant work
- Amazing salary/benefits
- Good work/life balance
cons:
- Company is massive, complex, and processes are constantly shifting
- Highly political culture -everything is done with promotion in mind, people treat work like a game of chess here. Doing your job is not enough (I once sat in a training where we were told explicitly that "consistently meets expectations" on a performance review was not an acceptable rating). This approach leads to burnout and some drama within teams.
Advice to Management
Hire more senior leaders with emotional intelligence. If you are only interested in the bottom line, your core values will erode over time and you will lose all the values that made Google such a remarkable company in the first place.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Lots of smart people tripping over one another
pros: pay and benefits, smart colleagues, excellent techology
cons:
Job scope narrow, lots of people doing similar roles, limited scope for innovation if you are not based at HQ. Some truly horrible people in very senior leadership roles who make life miserable for their organisations but everyone is too afraid to say anything. Easy to grow in the early stages of career - extremely difficult as you head towards Director level. Lots of senior leaders have their fiefdoms and 'friends' whom they take care of at the expense of other talent. Politics are hideous
Advice to Management
looks for efficiencies in the organisation, reduce superfluous staff, do anonymous feedback sessions for your senior leaders, you'll be astonished at what they are really like as opposed to their public personas

review_title: Great opportunities with absolutely abysmal management and zero direction
pros:
The people you work with
The opportunities
Working with modern stacks
Zero VPN setup
Good hardware selection choice
The health benefits
My manager
cons:
The program I was on
The Director
The management under the Director
Decisions made with no forethought
Advice to Management
The only advice I can provide to management is to actually self reflect on what they are doing. Managers are too focused on their own performance and what they can "contribute" to the organisation, creating an extremely toxic and competitive environment between themselves. Also there needs to be less reactive and more proactive initiatives. Nothing innovative; new or progressed during my time in the residency program.

Humble yourselves, listen to your staff and actually start acting appropriately. A plethora of managers were in the mindset of "They are only here for 20-26 months, the problem will go away". Do something out of the box, go against the grain, grow a spine and actually spearhead change.

The disparity between locations around the world was unfathomable. It is literally a roll of the dice whether you will have a good experience in the program based on the manager you were assigned to. I was extremely fortunate to have a fantastic supporting manager but my counterparts had a very different experience.

The director is not fit for their role. They hide behind their curtain making communication almost impossible. During all hands they were always stammering and choking on questions...the organisation needs a confident person at the helm that is able to answer questions without hesitation. The lack of strong leadership and direction always harmed morale.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: interesting preschool environment, typical lack of appreciation for educators
pros:
- work at a tech company and enjoy most of the benefits (if you can work It into your schedule)
- freedom in day to day work (*very team dependent)
- health insurance
cons:
- very low pay for the area - my recruiter literally told me my offer was considered "below a livable wage in the bay area", however I also had no room to negotiate based on experience ..lesson learned!
- unfair / biased hiring practices - theres at least one lawsuit in recent years alleging unequal pay between male and female teachers. I can confirm I knew of at least 1 male teacher who was hired as a level II when every female teacher I knew had been told by their recruiter they *must* start as a level I regardless of education or experience. I knew of at least one peer with a Masters who had to start as a level I - $16/hr. I am confident the male teacher did not have the same level of experience.
- unfair promotions - all about who you are friends with. if your team is a sinking ship you will likely go down with them at performance time regardless of your own individual performance
- HIGH attrition due to all of the above. constantly understaffed and making huge crazy sacrifices to stay in ratio 
- used to give stock options at hire - took them away without telling the population. huge uproar when everyone found out, followed by walk out protest and calls for raising base pay based on market standards. told by google leadership "we know educators being underpaid is a problem, but Google is not going to focus on that right now"
- few growth opportunities - only 3 levels of teacher when I was there in 2017, otherwise like a handful of operations and leadership positions. 
- base pay is bad but promotion compensation was worse, a slap in the face. when I was promoted from a level I to level II teacher (the 2nd of 3 levels I could aspire to, remember) my raise was literally less than a dollar + a few stock thank god, and my manager actually acted like It was a big deal. I cant really blame her, knowing now how some companies manage promotions and $$ when It comes down to It, but that was just insulting..for the both of us. not unusual for educators, especially in preschool, but Google sets their own standard high and when a company is always preaching how "employee first" they are you kind of get to hold them accountable to it in practice.
Advice to Management
advocate better for your teachers. you have all the power and they are doing all the dirty work. show up for them first - with parents, with google & the compensation team or internal mobility team. Treat them just as well - no *better* - than they treat the kids. Focus on why you are losing people, listen to their experiences, and find solid solutions for them. Put people with actual people management skills in leadership roles.

review_title: An amazing and dynamic place to work
pros: Given the resources and autonomy to work on problems that matter and energize. I am given scope and guidance to really excel in this amazing environment with incredibly smart and kind co-workers. The office is energizing and so much fun, I truly love going to work every day and consider myself incredibly well looked after.
cons:
Working from home during 2020 has been tough but I think we have been cared for as well as possible through this period. As the company grows it does lose its high-energy and weird feeling to some extent although there are concerted efforts to minimize the erosion of company culture.

pros:
* Lots of really smart people, I learned way more here than anywhere else I've worked.
* Great salaries and benefits; free food, gym, laundry, etc. If I wasn't married I might have just bought a van and lived in the parking lot.
* Work/life balance was pretty solid, culture was fantastic.
cons:
* Everything is about your promotions and job number. Promotion is notoriously fickle, the metrics-driven approach tends to create behavior that isn't ideal.
* Work is not terribly interesting unless you're you're 99.9% percentile type.
* Outside of the major offices you're not going to advance very much. This is more of a job for when you want to kick back and relax rather than be ambitious.

review_title: Google is an amazing place to work for the people, the growth, scale, variety and perks!
pros:
-) The people (coworkers are smart & nice). 
-) The growth (you willl get invaluable development feedback from 360 degree reviews, that, if you are able to internalize and incorporate the feedback, will propel your career forward)
-) Variety. So many groups in one place, that when you're ready for your next career exploration, it will be easy and smooth. Google wants to be the last place you'll ever work.
-) Scale. If you want to have lots of users, in some cases billions, Google is a lot of fun and you are helping many people who use your product directly or indirectly. 
-) Free food and stocked "micro-kitchens" with snacks. And, the shuttles (okay, in 2020-21 this isn't a factor, but it will be when we all go back.)
Help the environment and make friends with neighbors, while riding a climate controlled bus with leather seats and friendly bus drivers, to work & back. If you can read in cars, you also will probably be able to get all your email done on the way to and from work, and the day is just about getting real work done.
cons:
It is a large company, with over 100,000 employees, so there are often many people involved in any given project. You will need to be patient to work with stakeholders. Most teams have minimal politics so this goes smoothly. Things take longer than in a startup, but on the other hand, the scale of users, products, infrastructure is much greater.
Advice to Management
Look for ways to maintain velocity and nimbleness at scale.

review_title: Not safe for people of color
pros:
-The Google name opens doors.
-Nice people for the most part.
-Benefits and perks.
cons:
-Most employees are miserable. The golden handcuffs keep people there.
-Diversity and inclusion are just buzz words. They have no clue how to achieve either.
-If you speak up about inequality too much or too loudly they will find ways to push you out. Creating a culture of gaslighting, discrimination and structurally reinforced racism.
-Many employees are suffering in silence as a result.
-Most of the leadership have sold their souls for a paycheck.
Advice to Management
Stop paying your pr machines to push out information about all the “significant ways” you’re trying to make the company more diverse and inclusive, instead focus on dismantling all the systems that contribute to creating a toxic place for anyone that’s not white or Asian and male.

pros: You get to work with intelligent (socially and book smart) people constantly whether they are your customers or your coworkers. You don’t have to know Google Ads to start the role and they train you in the product very well. By a year in the role you’ll be in the 95% percentile of Google ads experts and you’ll have the opportunity to explore other roles at Google if you please. If you do well your pay goes through yearly refreshes and It can make a huge difference. You get to bring your whole self to work and that’s really cool.
cons:
If you are joining the role from another company It is very vague if you will come into the role as an L2 (hourly) or L3 and that can make a big difference in compensation. People with 2-3 years of experience can make the same as a college grad and that can be frustrating. While pay has the potential to go up if you perform well, promotions can feel slow due to only 2 cycles a year which can limit you from going to roles that require certain levels. You will be challenged and need to have discipline, but it’s not a cutthroat environment in the slightest everyone helps everyone.
Advice to Management
Continue showing a dedication to well being

review_title: Not the worst but will slowly wear down your soul
pros:
- The people are generally friendly, knowledgeable, and nice to work with (this may vary wildly from team to team)
- Good compensation/benefits/perks (aside from vacation)
- Good work autonomy
cons:
- Questionable leadership
- Only 15 days vacation
- Frequent org changes
- Promo/performance review process is time-consuming and demoralizing
- Software engineering work is so steeped in abstraction/monolithic systems and/or may be cancelled at any moment so it's difficult to feel any sort of satisfaction in your work
Advice to Management
Don't push out employees for voicing negative criticism. Take accountability for your actions.

pros: Google cloud is growing rapidly, and that opens up growth opportunities constantly. There's an unbelievable innovation pace, new products/features being released all the time. The people at Google is really the best, there's a lot of great talent, and while Google needs to continue to improve the diversity, specially on management roles, I think the Google Cloud team is fairly diverse.
cons:
There's a lot of change, and for some people this could be stressful, because there's a lot of adjustment needed. There are changes at all levels including compensation/salary changes. Another con is that in it's effort to catch up with the cloud market leaders, Google is becoming a traditional enterprise software company, and is loosing some of its values, culture, and identity.
Advice to Management
Don't let Google Cloud become an Oracle/IBM

review_title: Google is great for the most part, but some things can be improved
pros:
Great facilities when in office, and great support to work from home (they pay for your WiFi, desk set up, accessories, etc.)
Status of being a Googler
Competitive salary
cons:
Career growth is encouraged only as much as it serves Google's goals, and once you're in the company, it's a bit difficult to really progress
Dissent is not encouraged, as much as they say it is an "open culture" - this stifles some of the best ideas, and keeps open discussions from happening
Promotion is a political process much more than it is merit-based
Advice to Management
Get better at appreciating the beauty of different opinions

review_title: All in all, an outstanding place to work.
pros:
* The employee's fight to keep the company as "good" as possible.
* The business model allows for the company to provide outstanding free services (gmail, calendar, maps, etc)
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a con) which means that managers don't unilaterally decide who should get promoted based on biases and favoritism.
cons:
* The employees have grown to expect to continue to be treated extremely well (pay, benefits, and perks).
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a pro) which leads to a "do what makes you look good, not do what is good" perspective.
* Because most people make a lot of money, there is a wealth culture that exists and that at least bothers me.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros:
- lots of senior UXers you can learn from
- monetarily this is a great place to be a UXR. If you are good, you can expect a good pay trajectory. Great benefits & perks.
- lots of stability
cons:
- experience varies a LOT depending on the team & product
- If you like speed, this is not the place for you. Things are slow unless you are in a new bet area. 
- career growth is gradual..there are steps & you usually don't jump levels. (This can be a pro if you want to have slow & sustainable growth)
Advice to Management
Find ways to reduce UX management. It interferes with product impact.

Great co-workers

About as large-scale as it gets
cons:

Advice to Management
Google is special, but it's losing its appeal. Either return to your roots of being a daring, innovative company, or find a way to reinvent yourself. Do something about the stagnation before all the good people have gone elsewhere.

review_title: The job is really not that interesting |The company really cares
pros:
- Perks are great and you will use them (gym, food, pantry, education, insurance, dental, ...)
- Working for a big company logo helps to open doors and makes you ''an interesting'' person in the room
- In the right team and with the right portfolio, you can make a real difference to businesses and communities
- Very empathetic, inclusive, and open environment
- Job safety. If you do your job, are on time, do what you're asked, it's a road to retirement

Generally, I'd recommend this job to someone in their mid-20s looking for a career in one company with a lot of resources, or an older individual with less drive looking for a safe place.
cons:
- Some roles are really not as glamorous as the job description reads. In customer-facing roles, you will often find yourself being an extended arm of Customer Support filing tickets and following up
- Getting a promotion is a steep challenge and fairly political (You have to be visible to the directors and sign up for all kinds of projects to show your value. This isn't much of an issue to me personally, but many people view it as an unwanted obstacle).
- You have to master your calendar to have time to actually do a job you want to do (After filing tickets, attending a dozen training sessions, taking multiple internal meetings a day, and replying to your emails, there are days when you find yourself having only 2-3 hours to do the job you hoped to be doing when they hired you)
- Inter-office transfers are very difficult to accomplish
- Irish tax system isn't really income-friendly (for those coming from low-income tax countries, you'd be shocked with how much money is lost every month).

Generally, I'd recommend dynamic, hungry, and entrepreneurial people to consider a smaller scale company where feel like you're making a difference, you mean something and your work is tangible, and not just a digit in Google's multi-billion dollar revenue.

review_title: Great place to work if you're lucky enough to work on good stuff, get promoted
pros: Best people and culture and biggest scale of influence
cons:
Highly bureaucratic and unnecessarily complex. Hamstrings execs who typically can't make decisions on things so just let problems fester and people waste time working on things that don't matter
Advice to Management
Don't allow engineers to tank PM's performance reviews. Remove "complexity" from perf as a requirement because not everything needs to be as complicated as it is. Unnecessary complexity is why a lot of our stuff is unstable and slow (eg android and assistant)

pros: Still well paid and with decent work/life balance
cons:
When high speed growth is hard to achieve, managers are trying to grab cakes from each other. One way to do that is more and more non-sense projects. On the other hand, nobody really cares about the so-called moon shot projects, as they are doomed to fail due to either poor judgement initially or short patience in execution.

We really should have Elon Musk as our CEO after Larry quit. I believe we would have set feet on Mars already. LOL

review_title: As tech jobs go It's pretty good but I'm not sure I personally like it here
pros:
- smart, kind, helpful coworkers who want to see you succeed! 
- lots and lots of possible stuff to work on internally, bc google really does Everything
- the perks + good job stability
- good work life balance; my workload is totally manageable
- cool to work on stuff that so many people use
cons:
- the company (and codebase) is so big it will swallow you whole if you are not careful
- getting promoted / "growing" in your career is a big corporate game which feels slimy at times, to me 
- takes forever to launch anything. sometimes you will work for months and months at a time on something and the project will get cancelled. it's fine when this happens once but when it happens several times in a row it can be disheartening
- the culture of your specific team & manager kind of defines your experience
- can feel like a cog in the machine
Advice to Management
stop firing people mysteriously & then claiming you didn't

review_title: Overall good work environment, highly team dependent though
pros:
Google is well known for its perks. In non-covid times the offices are well equipped, all the snacks, food, gyms, massage rooms, nap pods. It's the stuff of much satire. It's very nice.

The compensation is really good. Collaboration across teams can be great, although it does depend on product area. The culture in the company and much of the scandal that comes out is born out of transparency and freedom. Freedom to express yourself many employers stomp down on and sometimes.... it's too much but usually it's quite freeing.
cons:
The promotion process at google is well intentioned but poor, IMO. It is honestly probably the single biggest reason google is known for abandoning products. We develop things for promotions because that's what gets them. Maintaining and improving or spending the energy to rebuild and transfer data doesnt get you a promotion.

You need to land something, but you also need to excel for over a year this dissuades people pushing to do something to try and get a promotion which is good but also disincentivizing. The whole thing is political, you need to land grab at times to get work other teams might be doing so they can't do it.... again so you can get promoted. If you land in the right place at the right time it is easy to move up, rising tides raise all ships. A bad manager, a bad product idea, can sink you even if you are doing good work.
Advice to Management
Fix perf/promo.

Helpful

pros: Google has great benefits (health insurance/vision/dental - all great), the facilities are amazing, employee perks and events are awesome. No one ever yells at you :)
cons:
There does not seem to be a lot of true transparency. There are always emails from senior leads explaining things but comes off very politically advised. Internally mobility does not seem like what it use to be. It has been very difficult for people to advance their careers. Work life balance, especially during the pandemic has not been great.
Advice to Management
I would advise, holding employees accountable who are not meeting the expectations or standards. Many dependable employees are burning out because they have had to pick up the work of others not performing. I believe it is finding a balance of addressing performance and mental health.

review_title: Scale is a Pro and a Con
pros: Scale up your impact by working for a company with billions of users, a culture that is focused on the right things, and brilliant coworkers.
cons:
Changing a system with billions of users is harder than changing smaller systems. Google today is cautious, deliberative, and process heavy. Much of what makes an engineer successful at Google today is their ability to navigate the hierarchy, build consensus, and document everything. If you want to crank out code, iterate quickly, or focus on technical tasks Google is not the place for you.
Advice to Management
Be more forthright with employees. A mea culpa is always preferred over corp-speak.

review_title: Generous to employees, hugely impactful to the world
pros:
Top tier compensation and benefits
Global company with lots of access to different culture, travel opportunities, recognition

cons:

Individual experiences vary wildly depending on background, location, teammates, managers, etc

review_title: Great Launchpad to Senior Strategy Roles
pros: Gain experience generating millions of dollars and managing tens of millions more. Alumni from other parts of Alphabet come speak all the time, so internal transfers are pretty transparent. It's Google, so benefits are top of the top. Free gourmet food that changes every day (with some popular staples), free dessert, free barista-made coffee, free snacks. And that's just the food, not to mention free gym, free rock climbing walls, free Ayco (Goldman Sachs) financial advice, free massages, etc. Plus, the people are super quirky, getting to know any one of them is so fascinating. There's always something that sticks out, like "oh! that's their special quirk". I remember my first day meeting people that came to Google from producing Emmy award-winning shows, are related to people that founded a literal sport, or have been to all continents. Google is full of incredibly smart people with interesting stories to tell.
cons:
There are a crazy amount of benefits that its hard to keep track of. The main ones are listed and obvious but some more niche ones, or office-specific perks (like the free Lime scooters for some locations) are harder to find unless you spot the email. Maybe its more of a west coast office thing, but people are very easy going. I kind of wish it were a bit more competitive and people would flex more. I'm proud of the work people are doing but they gotta speak up!
2 people found this review helpful

pros:
- Very competitive compensation, regular comp refresh 
- Smart coworkers, relatively horizontal structure (in sales) allows for collaboration
- No micromanagement, very flexible and balanced schedule 
- Opportunity to drive impact at scale, albeit in a very narrow part of the business 
- Ability to pursue new interests through 20% projects in other parts of the company 
- The best physical office environment you can imagine (personal trainers, peloton, lunch, etc.); some nice WFH covid perks to compensate in this time
cons:
- Massive company, lots of red tape to cut through when building anything new 
- Lost focus on the end-user in advertising sales, all about revenue numbers 
- Laborious promotion process, but yearly salary refresh helps with this 
- Very difficult to move between job ladders (ex. program mgmt vs. sales) despite outward appearance of career mobility; requires tenacity and patience to move around the company 
- "Googleyness" somewhat, but a more conventional company these days
